newsitem.title: USA: McDonnell Douglas won't challenge fighter decision.
newsitem.headline: McDonnell Douglas won't challenge fighter decision.

text.p: McDonnell Douglas Corp said it will not challenge a decision by the U.S. government to drop it from a three-way competition to build the next generation fighter jet for the U.S. and Britain.

"I wouldn't know what to protest right now," the company's chief executive Harry Stonecipher told reporters on Saturday in a teleconference. "I think generally protests waste a lot of money and if you look at the numbers upheld it's pretty small."

The Pentagon on Saturday dropped the St. Louis-based aerospace giant from a three-way competition to build a "joint strike fighter" that could mean over $170 billion to the winner in the 21st century.

Stonecipher said he does not expect lay-offs as a result, as only about 200 people were directly working on the program. However, he said the company will "make an evaluation of the reassignment of people" who were working on the program.
The contract to build at least 3,000 fighter jets was considered by industry experts to be crucial to McDonnell Douglas, which recently reduced its commercial aviation activities.

Less than two weeks ago, the company said it was scrapping plans to develop a long-range commercial jetliner. Stonecipher said Saturday's loss of the fighter jet contract will not change that decision.
